content.text: How far, in km, does the car travel in ½ hour at the speed shown in Fig. 1.1?
distance =   .........  \(km\)
On the axes shown in Fig. 1.2, draw a line representing the motion of the car \(\frac{1}{2}\) hour mentioned in **(a)**. Do not go beyond \(\frac{1}{2}\) hour
At the end of the \(\frac{1}{2}\) hour, the car reaches a region where the road begins to rise up into some mountains. The car climbs the mountains for a further \(\frac{1}{2}\) hour
During the climb, its speed steadily decreases to \(30\mathrm{km / hour.}\) The driver then stops the car so that he can admire the view
On Fig. 1.2, draw a line representing the climb and the stopping of the car.
A car is travelling along a level road at a steady speed. Fig. 1.1 shows the speedo
the car. A speedometer registers how fast the car is going
the volume of the added water,
volume =   .........  cm³
the mass of the added water,
the density of water, stating clearly the equation you are using
density =   .........
A student carries out an experiment to find the density of water, using a method slightly different from normal. In his method, he starts with a measuring cylinder conta
some water, and then adds more water to that already in the measuring cylinder
His experiment is illustrated in Fig. 2.1
The readings he obtains are as follows:
reading 1 53 cm³
reading 2 84 cm³
reading 3 205g
reading 4 238g
Calculate
Mark these forces on Fig. 3.1, using an arrow labelled \(70 000 \text{N}\) and an arrow labelled \(25 000 \text{N}\)
State the direction of this force
Calculate the size of this force
size of force =   .........  N
Suggest what might be causing this force
The train is travelling at constant speed, so there must be another horizontal force acting on it
What happens to the train?
Why does this happen?
Once the train has passed the station, the driver increases the engine's forward thrust
All other forces stay the same
A train is passing through a station at constant speed, as shown in Fig. 3.1. The horizontal
The engine produces a forward thrust of \(70 000 \text{N}\). There is a \(25 000 \text{N}\) force opposing the motion, due to friction in the wheels
Explain, in terms of molecules, how a gas causes a pressure on the walls of its co
At constant temperature, the pressure of a gas increases as its volume
At constant volume, the pressure of a gas increases as its temperature
Complete the following two sentences
The principle of conservation of energy states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed
What, then, _does_ happen to the energy supplied to a device such as a motor or a television?
From the information on Fig. 5.1, find the total energy provided for the viewer to see and hear the television during this programme
Suggest what happens to the rest of the energy supplied
Calculate how much energy is involved in (b)(ii)
Comment on the efficiency of the television
The television in Fig. 5.1 is switched on to watch a programme. During this time, \(720\mathrm{kJ}\) of electrical energy is supplied
On Fig. 6.1, use your ruler to draw another ray from the top of the object until it crosses the ray printed on the diagram
On Fig. 6.1, draw the image of the object
Which of the following descriptions fit the image formed by the lens? Tick **3** boxes
much larger than the object
much smaller than the object
same size as the object
upright
inverted
real
The object is moved to a position further from the lens
What differences are seen in the image, compared with the previous image?
The ray diagram in Fig. 6.1 shows one ray from the top of an object placed to the converging lens
Remote controllers for television sets send a beam of electromagnetic radiation television
Which region of the electromagnetic spectrum is used? Tick one box
Modern warfare often uses heat-seeking missiles
Which region of the electromagnetic spectrum is used? Tick one box
Injured legs may be checked for possible fractures using electromagnetic radiation
Which region of the electromagnetic spectrum is used? Tick one box
Mobile phones communicate using electromagnetic radiation
Which region of the electromagnetic spectrum is used? Tick one box
An electric current exists in a wire when ............................................. are made to flow in the wire
The current in a wire may be measured using an instrument called
The potential difference across a wire may be measured by connecting
.........  across the wire
Complete the following sentences
A length of resistance wire is connected in a simple series circuit
The current in it is 0.8A. The potential difference across it is 9.6 V
Calculate the resistance of the wire
resistance =   .........
the resistance in the circuit,
the current in the new wire when there is a potential difference of \(9.6\mathrm{V}\) across it, as before
The resistance wire in **(b)** is replaced by a greater length of wire from the same reel
Without further calculation, state the effect this has on
On Fig. 9.1, clearly label the coil
State two things that could be done to the apparatus shown in Fig. 9.1 in order to make the coil rotate more rapidly
Suggest how the coil could be made to rotate in the opposite direction
The coil in the d.c. motor in Fig. 9.1 is rotating as shown
In the space below, draw the circuit symbol for a switch
Which one of the switches is definitely dangerous to use with mains voltages?
State the reason for your answer to (b)(i)
Which switch is the most suitable for turning the lights on or off from within the laundry?
State the reason for your answer to (c)(i)
A laundry, where clothes are washed, is likely to have lots of steam and condens
The laundry is lit by three mains-voltage lamps. Fig. 10.2 shows the mains supply and the three lamps
Complete Fig. 10.2 by adding the switch and the wiring that will allow all three lamps to light at full brightness when the switch is on.
Fig. 10.1 shows four different types of switch
On Fig. 11.1, carefully draw the path of the electron beam between A and the line BC
The voltage across the plates is reversed. State what difference this makes to the path of the electron beam
Fig. 11.1 shows an electron beam about to enter, at point A, the electric field between
charged metal plates
Which of these substances has the greatest number of particles in the nucleus of its atoms?
Which of these substances has the least number of electrons in the orbits of a neutral atom?
Which of these substances are emitting particles?
Samples of each of these substances are decaying. Each sample starts with the same number of atoms
Which sample decays the most in one hour?
In the investigation of a blood circulation problem, a patient is given an injection containing one of these substances. The radiation needs to be detectable from outside the body
Which of the substances might be suitable for this use?
